Question: A 4-year-old boy presents with chronic constipation. He has no diarrhea or fecal soiling. His past medical history reveals an uneventful delivery, but his discharge home was delayed as he failed to pass his first stool within 48 hours. The child has been on stool softeners since then but still only has one stool every 5 to 7 days. What is the appropriate next management?
###Options:
A.  Stimulant laxative
B.  Rectal manometry and barium enema
C.  Plain radiographs of the abdomen
D.  Observation
E.  None

###Answer:
rationale:
The child may have Hirschsprung disease, given the lifelong history of constipation and dependence on stool softeners.

Only 3% of patients have fecal soiling.

Rectal manometry and barium enema will aid in the diagnosis, but definitive diagnosis is made by punch or suction biopsy.

The pathology will show an aganglionic bowel segment, and the treatment is surgical resection of the affected segment of the bowel.
model rationale: The correct answer is A. Stimulant laxative. The rationale for this is that the child has a history of delayed passage of meconium and has been on stool softeners for several years with only infrequent bowel movements. This suggests a possible motility disorder of the gastrointestinal tract, such as Hirschsprung disease. A stimulant laxative would help to stimulate bowel movements and may be beneficial in this case. Rectal manometry and barium enema Option B may be more appropriate if there is a suspicion of anorectal malformation or Hirschsprung disease, but they are not the firstline tests in this scenario. Plain radiographs of the abdomen Option C are not typically used to diagnose chronic constipation in children. Observation Option D may be reasonable if there is no concern for underlying pathology, but in this case, the history suggests the need for intervention. There is no indication for none Option E as the child is experiencing significant constipation that requires further management. Please note that the final decision regarding management should be made by a healthcare professional based on a thorough evaluation of the childs medical history and physical examination findings.

Question: A 68 year old woman is brought into hospital after becoming severely out of breath at home. Observations on arrival include a respiratory rate of 28 breathes per minute, blood pressure of 85/53mmHg, heart rate of 103 beats per minute and oxygen saturation of 87% on air. Blood urea is 6mmol/L and AMTS is 7/10 with no previous confusion. What is the CURB65 score for this patient?
###Options:
A.  1
B.  2
C.  3
D.  4
E.  5

###Answer:
rationale: The correct answer is 3. Her age is higher than 65 and so this gives her one point. Respiratory rate is below 30 breathes per minutes which means there isnt a point for that. Systolic blood pressure below 90mmHg and diastolic blood pressure below 60mmHg gives her another point. Blood urea is below 7mmol/L which means there isnt a point for that but with new onset confusion giving her a new AMTS of below 8/10 she gets another point. So her age, blood pressure and confusion give her a score of 3.
model rationale: The CURB65 score is used to assess the severity of communityacquired pneumonia CAP in older patients. It includes five criteria Confusion, Urea 7mmolL, Respiratory rate 30min, Blood pressure systolic 90mmHg or diastolic 60mmHg, and Age 65 years. The patient in this question has a respiratory rate of 28min, blood pressure of 8553mmHg, and a urea of 6mmolL, making the score 2. The patient is also over 65 years old, so the total score is 2. Therefore, the correct answer is B. 2.

Question: Lactational amenorrhea is useful as a method of contraception under the following conditions except? 
###Options:
A.  Infant nurses more than every 6 hours at night
B.  The infant is not supplemented with formula
C.  3 months post natal
D.  exclusive breastfeeding
E.  Infant nurses less than every 6 hours at night

###Answer:
rationale: Lactational amenorrhoea is an effective method of contraception. Individuals must breast feed exclusively, feeding every 4 hours in the day and 6 hours at night. When individuals have their first menstrual period, reach 6 months old and their infant feeds less often this method is no longer effective
A: Infant nurses more than every 6 hours at night
B: The infant is not supplemented with formula
E: Infant nurses less than every 6 hours at night
model rationale: The correct answer is E. Infant nurses less than every 6 hours at night. Lactational amenorrhea is a method of contraception that relies on the absence of menstruation due to the suppression of gonadotropinreleasing hormone GnRH by high levels of prolactin in response to frequent nursing. The method is most effective when the infant is exclusively breastfed and nurses frequently, especially at night. Infants who nurse less than every 6 hours at night may not suppress GnRH sufficiently to prevent ovulation, reducing the effectiveness of lactational amenorrhea as a contraceptive method. Therefore, option E is the exception to the conditions under which lactational amenorrhea is useful as a method of contraception.

Question: A 16-year-old girl presents with injuries sustained in a serious motorcycle crash. Her signs and symptoms include (1) bilateral loss of pain and thermal sense within the area of the fracture, (2) lower motor neuron symptoms and vasomotor paralysis in areas supplied by the injured segments on the right side, (3) loss of sensory impulses in the posterior white columns below the lesion on the right side, and (4) upper motor neuron lesion below the level of injury on the right side. Imaging identifies a fracture-dislocation of a vertebra. The symptoms described are most suggestive of which of the following?
###Options:
A.  Traumatic syringomyelia
B.  Anterior spinal cord syndrome
C.  Posterior spinal cord syndrome
D.  Brown-Sequard syndrome
E.  Horner syndrome

###Answer:
rationale:
Brown-Sequard syndrome characteristically results following hemisection of the spinal cord.

It is characterized by loss of motor function on the side of the lesion and loss of protopathic sense on the contralateral side.

It is most commonly caused by penetrating or blunt trauma but can also be caused by mass-occupying lesions, bleeding disorders, and disc herniations.

Syringomyelia typically results in the loss of pain and temperature sensations in the cape-like patterns. Anterior cord syndrome results in loss of motor as well as pain and temperature below the level of spinal injury. Posterior cord syndrome results in loss of proprioception and vibration sensation below the level of injury.
model rationale: The correct answer is D. BrownSequard syndrome. The symptoms described are characteristic of BrownSequard syndrome, which is a spinal cord injury that results in a hemisection of the spinal cord. This injury leads to loss of pain and thermal sense ipsilaterally right side, lower motor neuron symptoms and vasomotor paralysis contralaterally left side, loss of sensory impulses in the posterior white columns below the lesion on the right side, and upper motor neuron lesions below the level of injury on the right side. The imaging findings of a fracturedislocation of a vertebra are consistent with the mechanism of injury that can cause BrownSequard syndrome. Traumatic syringomyelia A typically presents with a painless, progressive sensory loss and may have a history of trauma, but it does not usually present with the combination of symptoms described. Anterior spinal cord syndrome B typically presents with loss of pain and temperature sense, as well as loss of motor function below the level of the lesion, but does not usually present with the specific combination of symptoms described. Posterior spinal cord syndrome C typically presents with loss of proprioception and vibration sense, which is not described in this case. Horner

Question: White cells whose granules contain heparin, histamine and 5-hydroxytryptamine are a/an:
###Options:
A.  Neutrophil
B.  Eosinophil
C.  Basophil
D.  Band neutrophil
E.  None of the above

###Answer:
rationale: Basophils are a type of white blood cell that contain heparin, histamine, and 5-hydroxytryptamine (also known as serotonin). These granules are released by basophils during an immune response and play a role in inflammation and allergic reactions. Neutrophils, eosinophils, and band neutrophils are other types of white blood cells, but they do not contain these specific granules. Therefore, the correct answer is basophil.
model rationale: The correct answer is C. Basophil. Basophils are a type of white blood cell that contains granules rich in heparin, histamine, and 5hydroxytryptamine. These granules play a role in the bodys immune response and allergic reactions. Neutrophils, eosinophils, and band neutrophils do not contain these specific granules. Therefore, the correct answer is C. Basophil. Rationale Basophils are characterized by their unique granules, which contain heparin, histamine, and 5hydroxytryptamine. These granules are involved in various physiological processes, including inflammation, immune responses, and allergic reactions. Neutrophils, on the other hand, are granulocytes that contain neutrophilic granules, which do not contain heparin, histamine, or 5hydroxytryptamine. Eosinophils contain eosinophilic granules, which have a different composition. Band neutrophils are immature neutrophils and do not have the same granule content as basophils. Therefore, the correct answer is C. Basophil.

Question: Which of the following is a complication of untreated streptococcal pharyngitis (strep throat)?
###Options:
A.  Chronic sinusitis
B.  Psoriasis
C.  Urinary tract infection
D.  Gastroenteritis
E.  Rheumatic fever

###Answer:
rationale: Rheumatic fever is a serious complication of untreated streptococcal pharyngitis caused by group A Streptococcus bacteria. It can lead to inflammation of the heart, joints, skin, and central nervous system.
model rationale: The answer is E Rheumatic fever. Untreated streptococcal pharyngitis can lead to complications such as rheumatic fever, which is an inflammatory disease that can affect the heart, joints, skin, and brain. The other options listed are not typically complications of strep throat. Chronic sinusitis is more commonly associated with chronic respiratory infections or allergies. Psoriasis is a chronic skin condition that is not directly related to strep throat. Urinary tract infections and gastroenteritis are not usual complications of streptococcal pharyngitis.

Question: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents to discuss results of a biopsy done 3 days ago for a rapidlyenlarging neck mass. He first noted the mass 1 month ago. Two weeks ago, he was evaluated for an episode of prolongedepistaxis and was found to have a right ear effusion, which was treated with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid. He has no otherhistory of serious illness and takes no medications. Height is at the 10th percentile, weight is at the 50th percentile, andBMI is at the 75th percentile. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a right ear effusion anda 4-cm, firm mass in the right posterior triangle of the neck. Results of a biopsy specimen show squamous epitheliumwith indistinct cell margins, enlarged atypical nuclei, and absent keratin formation. Which of the following infectiousagents is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current condition?
###Options:
A.  Cytomegalovirus
B.  Epstein-Barr virus
C.  HIV
D.  Human herpesvirus 8

###Answer:
rationale: The clinical presentation described, including the presence of a rapidly enlarging neck mass with histopathological findings of squamous epithelium with indistinct cell margins, enlarged atypical nuclei, and absent keratin formation, suggests a diagnosis of lymphoepithelial carcinoma, also known as undifferentiated nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC).Undifferentiated NPC is strongly associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection. EBV is known to be closely linked to the pathogenesis of NPC, particularly the undifferentiated subtype, through its ability to infect and transform epithelial cells in the nasopharynx.Therefore, among the options provided, the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current condition is:(B) Epstein-Barr virus
model rationale: The correct answer is B. EpsteinBarr virus. The patients symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with a diagnosis of nasopharyngeal carcinoma, which is commonly associated with EpsteinBarr virus EBV infection. The presence of a neck mass, ear effusion, and the patients age are all suggestive of this diagnosis. The biopsy findings of squamous epithelium with atypical nuclei and absence of keratin formation are also consistent with nasopharyngeal carcinoma. While other viruses such as CMV, HIV, and HHV8 can cause malignancies, EBV is the most commonly associated with nasopharyngeal carcinoma. The patients height at the 10th percentile, weight at the 50th percentile, and BMI at the 75th percentile suggest normal growth patterns, making malnutrition an unlikely cause of the mass. The absence of medications and serious illness in the patients past also makes druginduced or autoimmune causes less likely. Overall, the combination of symptoms, physical examination findings, and biopsy results point towards an infectious cause, with EBV being the most likely agent responsible for the patients current condition.

Question: A 9-year-old boy was conservatively managed for an appendicular mass. The parents enquire whether to have an interval appendicectomy to prevent the chances of having appendicitis again. What percentage of patients with conservatively managed appendix mass are likely to develop recurrent appendicitis?
###Options:
A.  80-100%
B.  40-60%
C.  0-20%
D.  60-80%
E.  20-40%

###Answer:
rationale: The chance of having appendicitis again after appendix mass is around 17% in children. While the traditional teachings by Hamilton Bailey recommend following the conservative Ochsner-Sherren regimen followed by an interval appendicectomy six weeks after the discharge of the patient, there remains a looming controversy whether to perform an interval appendicectomy or not.
model rationale: The correct answer is C. 020. Rationale In patients who have had a previous appendicular mass a complication of acute appendicitis, the risk of recurrent appendicitis after conservative management is low, ranging from 0 to 20. This is because the initial inflammation and complications have already occurred, and the risk of future inflammation is reduced. Interval appendectomy, which is the surgical removal of the appendix between 2 and 8 weeks after the initial episode, is not typically recommended unless there is a strong suspicion of ongoing or recurrent appendicitis. In most cases, the risks associated with surgery outweigh the potential benefits in preventing a rare recurrence. Therefore, it is not necessary for the parents to consider an interval appendicectomy in this scenario, as the risk of recurrent appendicitis is low.

Question: A 40-year-old man presents with low back pain. A lumbar MRI shows a herniated disk. Conservative treatment is recommended with pain management, bed rest, and subsequent physical therapy. For the acute phase, naproxen, morphine, and cyclobenzaprine are prescribed to control the pain. The patient calls the clinic and complains of persistent pain. He took his medications only 2 hours ago. What is the most rational next step in management?
###Options:
A.  Prepare for patient-controlled analgesia
B.  Administer another dose of morphine
C.  Give intramuscular placebo
D.  Ask for the nature, pattern, and characteristics of pain
E.  none

###Answer:
rationale:
More information about pain characteristics is needed before deciding which medication should be given to the patient.

If the pain is related to muscle spasms, cyclobenzaprine would be most appropriate.

If the pain is severe, morphine should be given.

If the pain is mild to moderate, naproxen should be given.
D: Ask for the nature, pattern, and characteristics of pain
model rationale: The most rational next step in management is D. Ask for the nature, pattern, and characteristics of pain. Explanation The patients complaint of persistent pain after taking his medications suggests that the current treatment plan may not be effectively managing his symptoms. Before considering changing or escalating treatment, it is crucial to gather more information about the patients pain. Asking for the nature, pattern, and characteristics of the pain can provide valuable insights into the underlying cause and severity of the pain. This information will help determine whether the current treatment is adequate or if adjustments need to be made. Administering another dose of morphine option B without assessing the patients pain may lead to increased medication use and potential side effects without addressing the underlying issue. Preparing for patientcontrolled analgesia option A is not indicated at this stage as it is typically used for patients with severe, intractable pain that is not wellcontrolled with oral medications. Giving intramuscular placebo option C is not a recommended or ethical practice without clear evidence of a placebo effect in this context. Option E, none, is not a valid choice as the patient has expressed dissatisfaction with his current treatment and needs further evaluation and management.

Question: Which condition is characterized by the enlargement of the prostate gland, leading to urinary symptoms like frequent urination and difficulty initiating urination?
###Options:
A.  Prostatitis
B.  BPH
C.  Prostate cancer
D.  Testicular torsion
E.  Erectile dysfunction

###Answer:
rationale: Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is a common condition in older men characterized by non-cancerous enlargement of the prostate gland, often causing urinary problems.
model rationale: The correct answer is B. BPH. Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia BPH is a condition where the prostate gland enlarges, which can lead to urinary symptoms such as frequent urination, difficulty initiating urination, and incomplete bladder emptying. Prostatitis refers to inflammation of the prostate gland, which can also cause urinary symptoms but is not characterized by the enlargement of the prostate. Prostate cancer is a malignant condition that can also affect the prostate gland, but it typically presents with different symptoms such as hematuria blood in the urine and may require different treatment approaches. Testicular torsion is a condition that affects the testicles, not the prostate gland, and typically presents with sudden, severe pain in the scrotum. Erectile dysfunction is a condition characterized by difficulty achieving or maintaining an erection and is not directly related to the symptoms of an enlarged prostate. Therefore, the correct answer is B. BPH.

Question: A 56-year-old woman with hypertension, a family history of coronaryartery disease, tobacco use, and depression recently underwentmenopause and now seeks your advice regarding alcoholconsumption. She admits to a few bouts of binge drinking in her 20sbut denies having any alcoholic beverages over the past 30 years.Because she has heard that alcohol use can reduce heart disease,she would like to know if she should drink a few glasses of wine everynight.Which of the following is the most appropriate response?
###Options:
A.  Advise the patient not to begin alcohol consumption
B.  Advise the patient to consume 1-2 alcoholic beverages daily
C.  Advise the patient to consume 3-4 alcoholic beverages daily
D.  Advise the patient to consume at least 3 alcoholic beverages at a time, but only on weekends

###Answer:
rationale: Available data suggest an association between regular, moderate (1-2 drinks/daily)alcohol consumption and lower rates of myocardial infarction, stroke, and all-causemortality. In addition, regular, moderate alcohol intake may be associated with lowerlevels of coronary calcification, reduced postprandial glucose, and less incidentdiabetes mellitus. However, less frequent and higher levels of alcohol use appear toreverse these trends. For this reason, answers C and D are incorrect.Whether patients who do not currently use alcohol should begin to do so remainscontroversial. At present, there are insufficient data to justify a universalrecommendation for initiating alcohol consumption in nondrinking patients and thelatest AHA guidelines discourage this, in part because of the risk of dependence andpotential adverse consequences of alcohol intoxication. For this reason, in light ofthis patient's history of smoking and depression, the most prudent course isprobably for her to remain abstinent of alcohol use.
A: Advise the patient not to begin alcohol consumption
B: Advise the patient to consume 1-2 alcoholic beverages daily
C: Advise the patient to consume 3-4 alcoholic beverages daily
D: Advise the patient to consume at least 3 alcoholic beverages at a time, but only on weekends
model rationale: The most appropriate response is A. Advise the patient not to begin alcohol consumption. Explanation While moderate alcohol consumption may have some cardiovascular benefits, it is not recommended for individuals who have never consumed alcohol before or who have a history of heavy or binge drinking. The patient in this scenario has a significant risk factor for cardiovascular disease CVD including hypertension, a family history of CVD, tobacco use, and depression. Additionally, she recently went through menopause, which can also increase the risk of CVD. Given her risk factors, it would be safer to advise her not to start consuming alcohol, as it may not provide any additional cardiovascular benefits and could potentially exacerbate her risk factors. It is important to emphasize lifestyle modifications such as maintaining a healthy diet, regular exercise, smoking cessation, and stress management as primary strategies for reducing CVD risk.

Question: Which of the following is not a common neurological
 complication of cardiac bypass?

###Options:
A.  Stroke
B.  Encephalopathy
C.  Demyelinating polyneuropathy
D.  Brachial plexopathy
E.  Seizure

###Answer:
rationale: Demyelinating polyneuropathy isn't frequently linked with cardiac bypass procedures. Strokes typically occur due to emboli in this context, with the risk varying based on the type of surgery and medical conditions. Brachial plexopathy is often caused by traction or compression injuries, leading to weakness or numbness in the upper extremities. Acute encephalopathy may be seen in 3%32% of patients post-bypass, while chronic cognitive issues, known as postpump syndrome, can emerge within weeks. The prevalence of cognitive issues post-bypass ranges from 3%79%, and seizures are reported in 0.5%3.5% of patients after coronary artery bypass surgery.
model rationale: The answer is D. Brachial plexopathy. Brachial plexopathy is not a common neurological complication of cardiac bypass. The other options listed are known complications. Stroke can occur due to embolism or hypoperfusion. Encephalopathy is a common postoperative complication, often due to hypoxia or cerebral vasospasm. Demyelinating polyneuropathy is a wellknown complication, typically occurring 34 days after surgery and often reversible. Seizures can also occur as a result of cerebral hypoxia or metabolic disturbances. Brachial plexopathy, on the other hand, is more commonly associated with other conditions such as trauma, infection, or radiation therapy, but not typically with cardiac bypass surgery. Therefore, the correct answer is D. Brachial plexopathy.

Question: What condition occurs when light passing through the cornea is not properly focused on the retina and distance and close vision may appear blurry?
###Options:
A.  Diplopia
B.  Nystagmus
C.  Astigmatism
D.  Entropion
E.  none of the above

###Answer:
rationale: In Astigmatism, the cornea is shaped like a football thus the above effect is seen
model rationale: The answer is C. Astigmatism. Astigmatism occurs when the cornea or lens is irregularly shaped, causing light to focus on two or more points on the retina instead of one. This can result in blurry vision at both near and far distances. Diplopia is double vision, which can be caused by a variety of factors but is not specifically related to the condition described. Nystagmus is an involuntary movement of the eyes, which can also be caused by a range of conditions but is not directly related to the refractive error described. Entropion is a condition where the eyelid turns inward, which can cause the eyelashes to rub against the cornea and lead to eye irritation, but it does not affect the focusing of light on the retina. Therefore, the correct answer is C. Astigmatism.user

Question: The following intervention is commonly used to manage Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH)?
###Options:
A.  Administration of antihypertensive medications
B.  Intravenous administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics
C.  Uterine massage and administration of oxytocin
D.  Immediate neonatal breastfeeding initiation
E.  none of the above

###Answer:
rationale: The most common intervention for managing postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) involves uterine massage and the administration of oxytocin.PPH is defined as excessive bleeding following childbirth, and active management of the third stage of labor, including the use of uterotonic agents like oxytocin, is critical for preventing and treating this condition.Oxytocin promotes uterine contractions, which help to constrict the blood vessels in the uterus and reduce bleeding.
C: Uterine massage and administration of oxytocin
model rationale: The correct answer is C. Uterine massage and administration of oxytocin. This intervention is commonly used to manage Postpartum Hemorrhage PPH as it helps to stimulate uterine contractions and reduce bleeding. The other options, such as administration of antihypertensive medications, intravenous administration of broadspectrum antibiotics, and immediate neonatal breastfeeding initiation, are not typically used as firstline interventions for managing PPH. However, antihypertensive medications may be used in cases of severe hypertension, and antibiotics may be used if there is suspicion of infection, such as endometritis. Immediate neonatal breastfeeding initiation is generally encouraged, but it is not a direct intervention for managing PPH. The rationale for choosing C. Uterine massage and administration of oxytocin is that it directly addresses the underlying issue of uterine atony, which is a common cause of PPH. By stimulating uterine contractions, this intervention helps to compress the blood vessels and reduce bleeding. Oxytocin, a hormone that stimulates uterine contractions, is often administered intramuscularly or intravenously to enhance the effectiveness of uterine massage. This combination is a standard approach for managing mild to moderate

Question: Which of the following factors contribute to the increase in cardiac output in pregnancy?
###Options:
A.  Decrease in blood volume
B.  Increase in ejection fraction
C.  Increases in heart rate
D.  Increase in left ventricular stroke work index
E.  Increase in systemic vascular resistance

###Answer:
rationale: The heart rate increases during pregnancy to meet the increased metabolic demands of both the mother and the fetus which augments cardiac output.Other factors that contribute to increase in CO in pregnancy are:-Increase in blood volume-Increase in stroke volume-Decrease in systemic vascular resistance
D: Increase in left ventricular stroke work index
model rationale: The correct answer is B. Increase in ejection fraction. A rationale for this answer is that during pregnancy, there is a physiological increase in cardiac output to meet the increased metabolic demands of the mother and the developing fetus. This increase in cardiac output is primarily achieved through an increase in ejection fraction, which is the percentage of blood that is pumped out of the left ventricle with each heartbeat. The other options listed do not contribute to the increase in cardiac output during pregnancy. Decrease in blood volume option A is not a contributing factor as blood volume actually increases during pregnancy. Increases in heart rate option C contribute to the increase in cardiac output, but they are not the primary mechanism. Increase in left ventricular stroke work index option D refers to the amount of force needed for the left ventricle to pump blood, and it does not directly contribute to the increase in cardiac output. Increase in systemic vascular resistance option E would actually work against an increase in cardiac output, as it would require the heart to work harder to push blood through the vessels. Therefore, the most accurate answer is B. Increase in ejection fraction.

Question: A 13 month old baby was taken to the hospital after his father saw that he had periorbital oedema for two days. He is seen by the doctor and noted to have facial oedema and a tender distended abdomen. His temperature is 39.1 and his blood pressure is 91/46 mmHg. There is also clinical evidence of poor peripheral perfusion. What is the diagnosis?
###Options:
A.  Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis
B.  Intussusception
C.  Sickle cell crisis
D.  Henoch Schönlein purpura
E.  Appendicitis

###Answer:
rationale: Spontaneous bacterial peritonitisThe presence of periorbital and facial oedema with normal blood pressure in this toddler indicates that he has nephrotic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome can be associated with a series of complications that can affect an individuals health and quality of life:Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis can develop where there is ascites present. This is a frequent development in children but very rarely found in adults.Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is the development of a bacterial infection in the peritoneum, despite the absence of an obvious source for the infection. It is specifically an infection of the ascitic fluid  an increased volume of peritoneal fluid. Ascites is most commonly a complication of cirrhosis of the liver. It can also occur in patients with nephrotic syndrome. SBP has a high mortality rate.The diagnosis of SBP requires paracentesis, a sampling of the peritoneal fluid taken from the peritoneal cavity. If the fluid contains large numbers of white blood cells known as neutrophils (>250 cells/µL), infection is confirmed and antibiotics will be given, without waiting for culture results. In addition to antibiotics, infusions of albumin are usually administered.Signs and symptoms of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) include fevers, chills, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain and tenderness, general malaise, altered mental status, and worsening ascites. Thirteen percent of patients have no signs or symptoms. In cases of acute or chronic liver failure SBP is one of the main triggers for hepatic encephalopathy, and where there is no other clear causal indication for this, SBP may be suspected.These symptoms can also be the same for a spontaneous fungal peritonitis (SFP) and therefore make a differentiation difficult. Delay of diagnosis can delay antifungal treatment and lead to a higher mortality rate.
model rationale: The answer is C. Sickle cell crisis. Sickle cell crisis is characterized by vasoocclusive episodes that can cause severe pain, ischemia, and organ damage. The patients symptoms of facial edema, distended abdomen, poor peripheral perfusion, and fever are consistent with a sickle cell crisis. In particular, the combination of facial edema and abdominal distension suggests the possibility of hepatic and splenic infarctions, which are common in sickle cell crisis. Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis typically presents with fever and abdominal pain, but without the specific signs of hepatic and splenic involvement seen in this patient. Intussusception usually presents with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, but not necessarily with edema or distension. Henoch Schnlein purpura is a vasculitis that typically presents with palpable purpura, arthritis, and abdominal pain, but not with the specific signs of hepatic and splenic infarction seen in this patient. Appendicitis typically presents with localized abdominal pain, rebound tenderness, and fever, but not with the systemic signs of sickle cell crisis. Therefore, based on the patients presentation, the most likely diagnosis is a sickle cell crisis.

Question: A 25-year-old girl gave birth to a healthy term infant through spontaneous vaginal delivery, and she is breastfeeding her child for the last two months. She previously had issues of bilateral breast pain for which she used primrose oil and vitamin E along with over-the-counter pain medication mostly ibuprofen. She said she had no issues with breast pain during pregnancy until a few days ago when her pain resurfaced, especially in her left breast. On physical examination, the left breast was seen to be swollen and tender to touch for the past week. The patient also has a fever of 38.2 degrees Centigrade. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her breast pain?
###Options:
A.  Fibrocystic change
B.  Traumatic suckling causing fat necrosis
C.  Bacterial infection of the breast
D.  Galactocele because of milk entrapment
E.  Dysplasia

###Answer:
rationale:
Acute mastitis is a bacterial infection of the breast most commonly due to Staphylococcus aureus. During breastfeeding, fissures develop in the nipple that provides a route of entry for microbes.

It generally presents as a swollen, tender breast with or without a localized area of erythema.

Sometimes it may present with purulent nipple discharge and can even progress to form a breast abscess.

Treatment involves oral antibiotics and continuous drainage of milk, especially with a breast pump.
model rationale: The correct answer is C. Bacterial infection of the breast. The patients symptoms of unilateral breast pain, swelling, and tenderness, along with a fever, suggest an infection. This is further supported by the history of using overthecounter pain medication, which may mask other signs of infection. The use of primrose oil and vitamin E for previous breast pain does not typically cause recurrent breast pain with an infection. Fibrocystic change and traumatic suckling causing fat necrosis are less likely causes in this scenario. Galactocele is usually not painful unless it becomes infected. Dysplasia is a term used to describe abnormal cell growth, which is not directly related to the patients symptoms. Therefore, the most likely cause of her breast pain is a bacterial infection of the breast.

Question: Which of the following hormones is NOT directly regulated by the pituitary gland, but indirectly influences its activity through negative feedback mechanisms?
###Options:
A.  Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH)
B.  Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone (TSH)
C.  Antidiuretic Hormone (ADH)
D.  Luteinizing Hormone (LH)

###Answer:
rationale: ADH is unique in that its release is primarily regulated by the hypothalamus, specifically the supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei. These nuclei produce ADH in response to changes in blood osmolality and blood volume. ADH is then stored and released by the posterior pituitary gland. However, the release of ADH is ultimately controlled by negative feedback mechanisms, where changes in blood osmolality or volume trigger either the release or inhibition of ADH production. Therefore, while the pituitary gland indirectly influences ADH release, it is not directly regulated by the anterior or posterior pituitary gland as the other hormones listed are.
model rationale: The correct answer is C. Antidiuretic Hormone ADH. ADH is not directly regulated by the pituitary gland, but its levels in the blood can affect pituitary function through negative feedback mechanisms. Rationale ADH, also known as vasopressin, is produced by the hypothalamus and released from the posterior pituitary gland. Its primary function is to regulate water balance in the body by increasing water reabsorption in the kidneys. While the pituitary gland does not directly regulate ADH secretion, changes in ADH levels can indirectly influence pituitary function. For example, high levels of ADH can suppress the release of vasopressin, which in turn can affect the release of other hormones from the pituitary gland. Therefore, although ADH is released from the pituitary gland, it is not directly regulated by the pituitary gland itself. Instead, it operates through a negative feedback mechanism to modulate pituitary activity. The other options, FSH, TSH, and LH, are all directly regulated by the pituitary gland. FSH and LH are released from the anterior pituitary gland in response to gonadotropinreleasing hormone

Question: A 63-year-old man presents with wheezing and dyspnea on exertion. He has a 35-pack-year smoking history, as well as a medical history of coronary artery disease, dyslipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His current medications are aspirin, atorvastatin, and metformin. Physical examination reveals marked bilateral wheezing. Laboratory test results including complete blood count and a basic metabolic profile are unremarkable. His spirometry this morning showed FEV1 of 75% and FEV1/FVC of 0.67. The clinician diagnoses the patient with COPD and prescribes a drug that is delivered via an inhaler. He tells the patient that the drug will cause some dizziness and blurring of vision. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
###Options:
A.  Beta-2 adrenergic agonist
B.  Phosphodiesterases inhibitor
C.  Anticholinergic
D.  Lipoxygenase enzyme inhibitor
E.  Antihistamine

###Answer:
rationale:
Ipratropium is an anticholinergic that inhibits parasympathetic bronchoconstriction.

It is used in the treatment of COPD and is usually administered through an inhaler.

Side effects of ipratropium therapy include headache, nausea, blurriness of vision, and constipation.

Zileuton can inhibit the enzyme lipoxygenase. Albuterol is a beta-2 adrenergic agonist. Theophylline is a phosphodiesterase inhibitor.
model rationale: The correct answer is A. Beta2 adrenergic agonist. The drug prescribed to the patient is a beta2 adrenergic agonist, which acts by stimulating the beta2 adrenergic receptors on the smooth muscles of the airways, causing bronchodilation. This results in improved airflow and relief of symptoms such as wheezing and dyspnea. The side effects of dizziness and blurring of vision are consistent with the known cardiovascular effects of beta2 agonists, which can include tachycardia and hypotension. Rationale Beta2 adrenergic agonists are the most commonly used medications for the treatment of COPD. They are effective bronchodilators that can rapidly improve lung function and alleviate symptoms. The mechanism of action involves binding to beta2 adrenergic receptors, which leads to the activation of adenylyl cyclase and an increase in intracellular cAMP levels. This results in the relaxation of bronchial smooth muscle and increased airway diameter. Phosphodiesterases inhibitors, such as sildenafil, are used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction and pulmonary arterial hypertension, but not typically for COPD. Anticholinerg

Question: A patient who has been treated for Parkinsons disease for about a year presents with purplish, mottled changes to her skin. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause?
###Options:
A.  Amantadine
B.  Bromocriptine
C.  Levodopa(alone)
D.  Levodopa + Carbidopa
E.  Pramipexole

###Answer:
rationale: This cutaneous response, called livedo reticularis , is characteristically associated with amantadine. Recall that this seldom-used antiparkinson drug probably works by releasing endogenous dopamine and blocking its neuronal reuptake. Livedo reticularis is not associated with levodopa (used with or without carbidopa), nor with the dopamine agonists bromocriptine or pramipexole. You might also recall that amantadine is also used for prophylaxis of some strains of influenza virus infections.
model rationale: The answer is A. Amantadine. Amantadine is known to cause hyperpigmentation of the skin, which can manifest as a mottled, purplish discoloration. This side effect is more common in patients with Parkinsons disease who are taking amantadine. Levodopa, bromocriptine, and pramipexole are not typically associated with this specific side effect. The rationale for this answer is based on the known side effects of amantadine, which can include hyperpigmentation of the skin. This side effect is more commonly seen in patients with Parkinsons disease who are taking amantadine as part of their treatment regimen. The other options, such as levodopa alone or in combination with carbidopa, and bromocriptine, are not typically associated with skin hyperpigmentation. Pramipexole is also not known to cause this side effect. Therefore, the most likely cause of the purplish, mottled changes to the patients skin is the use of amantadine.

Question: A 12-month-old boy presents for a well-child check. He started walking last week and can say "mama," "dada," "night-night," and "go." He eats a well-rounded diet and drinks whole milk twice a day. The patient lives with his mother, who is 17 weeks pregnant. His growth parameters and physical examination findings are normal. He is scheduled to receive measles-mumps-rubella, varicella, inactivated poliovirus, and pneumococcal conjugate vaccinations today. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
###Options:
A.  Administer all the scheduled vaccines.
B.  Administer all vaccines except the varicella vaccine.
C.  Defer all the scheduled vaccines until the mother delivers.
D.  Administer inactivated polio vaccine only.
E.  None

###Answer:
rationale:
Immunocompetent children can receive all standard immunizations regardless of the pregnancy status of household contacts. Although pregnant women should not receive live virus vaccines due to the theoretical risk of fetal infection, the risk of contracting an infection from a recipient of a live virus vaccine is very low.

The varicella vaccine can be administered safely to a patient who lives with a pregnant woman. The risk of a post-vaccination rash is very low. Isolation from a pregnant patient is unnecessary unless the vaccinated patient develops a rash.

Delaying vaccines until after pregnancy is not recommended as vaccines make it less likely that a child will contract the disease and bring it home to the mother. Infection with wild-type varicella and rubella poses a far more significant threat to a pregnant woman.

Pregnant women should not receive live virus vaccines, but their household members should get all routine immunizations on schedule.
B: Administer all vaccines except the varicella vaccine.
C: Defer all the scheduled vaccines until the mother delivers.
model rationale: The best next step in management is to administer all the scheduled vaccines. There is no contraindication to vaccinating this child based on his age, growth parameters, physical examination findings, or the fact that his mother is pregnant. The MMR, varicella, inactivated poliovirus, and pneumococcal conjugate vaccines are all recommended for children at this age, and there is no evidence to suggest that any of these vaccines are harmful to the fetus. Therefore, there is no reason to defer or withhold any of these vaccines. The answer is A Administer all the scheduled vaccines.

Question:  A 30-year-old lady presented to the University of Abuja Teaching Hospital with history of non-specific chest pain. On auscultation of the praecordium, there was wide fixed splitting of the second heart sound. What is the likely diagnosis?
###Options:
A.  Ventricular septal defect
B.  Tetralogy of Fallot
C.  Patent ductus arteriosus
D.  Atrial septal defect
E.  Biscuspid valve

###Answer:
rationale:
Based on the clinical findings of wide fixed splitting of the second heart sound on auscultation, the likely diagnosis is:

D. Atrial septal defect
model rationale: The correct answer is D. Atrial septal defect. The wide fixed splitting of the second heart sound indicates delayed closure of the pulmonary valve due to a lefttoright shunt across the atrial septal defect, which increases the volume of blood returning to the right side of the heart and prolongs the time it takes for the pulmonary valve to close. The other options are incorrect because they do not typically cause a wide fixed splitting of the second heart sound. Ventricular septal defects and patent ductus arteriosus can cause a holosystolic murmur and a continuous murmur, respectively. Tetralogy of Fallot typically presents with cyanosis due to a righttoleft shunt. Bicuspid valve can cause aortic stenosis or regurgitation but does not typically cause a wide fixed splitting of the second heart sound. Therefore, the likely diagnosis in this case is an atrial septal defect. Rationale The presence of wide fixed splitting of the second heart sound is indicative of a delayed closure of the pulmonary valve. This is commonly seen in atrial septal defects due to the increased volume of blood returning to the right side of the heart, which prolongs the time it takes for the pulmonary valve to close

Question: Which of the following is a method of preventing the transmission of HIV (human immunodeficiency virus)?
###Options:
A.  Hand hygiene
B.  Condom use
C.  Oral antibiotics
D.  Isolation procedures
E.  Wearing of gloves

###Answer:
rationale: Condom use is an effective method of preventing the sexual transmission of HIV, along with other sexually transmitted infections (STIs). It is an important component of comprehensive HIV prevention strategies.
model rationale: The correct answer is B. Condom use. Condoms provide a physical barrier that helps prevent the exchange of bodily fluids, which can contain the virus, during sexual activity. This method is effective in reducing the risk of HIV transmission, especially when used consistently and correctly. Hand hygiene, oral antibiotics, and wearing gloves are not specific methods for preventing HIV transmission. Isolation procedures are used to prevent the spread of infectious diseases in healthcare settings, but they are not typically used for HIV prevention in the general population.

Question: A 25-year-old woman is evaluated for a 3-day history of malodorous vaginal discharge. She denies any itching or irritation. She has been sexually active with the same partner for 6 months, using condoms to avoid pregnancy. Her medical history is unremarkable. On physical examination, external genitalia are normal. Internal vaginal examination reveals a homogenous, white, malodorous discharge that does not adhere to the vaginal walls, without the presence of vaginal erythema. Bimanual examination reveals no cervical motion tenderness. Mixing the vaginal discharge with a normal saline preparation reveals the presence of clue cells. A 25-year-old woman is evaluated for a 3-day history of malodorous vaginal discharge. She denies any itching or irritation. She has been sexually active with the same partner for 6 months, using condoms to avoid pregnancy. Her medical history is unremarkable. On physical examination, external genitalia are normal. Internal vaginal examination reveals a homogenous, white, malodorous discharge that does not adhere to the vaginal walls, without the presence of vaginal erythema. Bimanual examination reveals no cervical motion tenderness. Mixing the vaginal discharge with a normal saline preparation reveals the presence of clue cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
###Options:
A.  Candidal vaginitis
B.  Trichomonas vaginalis
C.  Physiologic discharge
D.  Bacterial vaginosis
E.  None of the above

###Answer:
rationale: The most likely diagnosis in this case is bacterial vaginosis. Bacterial vaginosis is characterized by a malodorous vaginal discharge that is often white or gray in color. It does not typically cause itching or irritation. The presence of clue cells, which are vaginal epithelial cells covered with bacteria, is a characteristic finding in bacterial vaginosis. The absence of cervical motion tenderness and vaginal erythema also support this diagnosis. Candidal vaginitis and trichomonas vaginalis can cause similar symptoms but would typically present with different physical examination findings. Physiologic discharge is a normal finding and would not cause malodorous discharge.
model rationale: The correct answer is D. Bacterial vaginosis. The presence of a homogenous, white, malodorous discharge that does not adhere to the vaginal walls, along with the presence of clue cells, is highly suggestive of bacterial vaginosis. Candidal vaginitis typically presents with a thick, white, curdlike discharge that adheres to the vaginal walls and is often associated with vulvar irritation. Trichomonas vaginalis infection usually presents with a frothy, greenyellow, malodorous discharge and vulvar erythema. Physiologic discharge is typically thin, clear, and nonmalodorous. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis in this case is bacterial vaginosis.

Question: Which hormone is responsible for regulating blood glucose levels by promoting glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis?

###Options:
A.  Insulin
B.  Glucagon
C.  Cortisol
D.  Thyroxine

###Answer:
rationale: Glucagon is produced by the alpha cells of the pancreas and acts to increase blood glucose levels. It does this by stimulating glycogenolysis (breakdown of glycogen into glucose) in the liver and promoting gluconeogenesis (synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources). Insulin (option a) acts to lower blood glucose levels by promoting glucose uptake into cells and storage as glycogen. Cortisol (option c) is involved in stress response and metabolism, but its primary role in glucose metabolism is to promote gluconeogenesis. Thyroxine (option d) is a thyroid hormone that regulates metabolism but does not have a direct role in glucose regulation.
model rationale: The answer is B. Glucagon. Glucagon is a hormone produced by the pancreas that increases blood glucose levels by stimulating glycogenolysis the breakdown of glycogen into glucose and gluconeogenesis the production of glucose from noncarbohydrate sources. Insulin, on the other hand, decreases blood glucose levels by promoting the uptake of glucose by cells and its conversion into glycogen or fat. Cortisol, a hormone released in response to stress, also increases blood glucose levels but does so by promoting gluconeogenesis and inhibiting glucose uptake by cells. Thyroxine is a thyroid hormone that plays a role in metabolism but does not directly regulate blood glucose levels.

Question:  65-year-old female comes in for the evaluation of difficulty in swallowing. She feels that the food gets stuck in her throat. Her medical history is significant for iron-deficiency anemia, for which she is taking iron supplements. Vital signs are pulse rate 70/min, blood pressure 102/62 mmHg, respiratory rate 18/min, and temperature 98.6 F (37 C). Physical examination is unremarkable except for pallor. Lab shows hemoglobin 10.0 g/dL, hematocrit 34%, white blood cell count 6500/microL, platelets 270,000/microL sodium 138 mEq/L, potassium 4.7 mEq/L, and creatinine 0.8 mg/dL. What other findings can be seen with this condition?
###Options:
A.  Zenker diverticulum
B.  Mallory Weiss tear
C.  Esophageal varices
D.  Esophageal web
E.  Diverticulitis

###Answer:
rationale:
Plummer-Vinson Syndrome (PVS) presents as a classical triad of dysphagia, iron-deficiency anemia, and esophageal web. It is a rare medical condition and primarily affects women in the age group of 40 to 70.

It has been postulated that iron deficiency induces iron-dependent enzyme dysfunction, leading to oxidative stress and DNA damage in the epithelia of the esophageal mucosa. Repeated injury to epithelia due to iron deficiency leads to atrophy of mucosa and degradation of pharyngeal muscles, leading to the development of esophageal webs.

Although PVS is a rare diagnosis, there should be high clinical suspicion in patients with iron-deficiency anemia, one or more esophageal webs, and post-cricoid dysphagia.

Esophageal webs need to be dilated endoscopically. Typically used techniques include endoscopic balloon dilatation or Savary-Gilliard dilators. Therapeutic endoscopy denotes the rupture of the web with a small amount of fresh blood at the site of the web.
model rationale: The correct answer is D. Esophageal web. Iron deficiency anemia can lead to the development of esophageal webs, which are thin membranes that can cause difficulty in swallowing. This condition is more common in patients with iron deficiency anemia due to chronic blood loss. The other options listed are not typically associated with iron deficiency anemia. Zenker diverticulum is a pouch that can form in the throat and cause difficulty swallowing, but it is not directly related to iron deficiency anemia. Mallory Weiss tear is a tear in the lining of the esophagus that can occur with severe vomiting, but it is not a common complication of iron deficiency anemia. Esophageal varices are enlarged veins in the esophagus that can occur in patients with liver disease, and they are not typically seen in iron deficiency anemia. Diverticulitis is the inflammation or infection of small pouches in the colon, and it is not related to iron deficiency anemia. Therefore, the most likely finding in this patient with iron deficiency anemia and difficulty swallowing is an esophageal web. The rationale for the answer is based on the association between iron deficiency anemia and the development of esophageal webs, which can cause symptoms of dys

Question: A man is taking a number of medications, one of which appears to be interfering with the emission phase of the sexual act. Which of the following medications could cause this problem?
###Options:
A.  A medication that prolongs the duration of action of nitric oxide
B.  A medication that blocks the smooth muscle receptors for nitric oxide
C.  A medication that increases the release of nitric oxide
D.  A testosterone-like androgen compound
E.  An inhibitor of beta-adrenergic nervous system receptors

###Answer:
rationale: Emission is elicited by reflexes mediated by the beta-adrenergic nervous system. Beta adrenergic antagonists interfere with the reflex. None of the other choices is involved.
A: A medication that prolongs the duration of action of nitric oxide
B: A medication that blocks the smooth muscle receptors for nitric oxide
C: A medication that increases the release of nitric oxide
E: An inhibitor of beta-adrenergic nervous system receptors
model rationale: The correct answer is A. A medication that prolongs the duration of action of nitric oxide. Rationale A drug that prolongs the duration of action of nitric oxide can interfere with the emission phase of the sexual act by causing prolonged erections. Nitric oxide is a neurotransmitter that is responsible for relaxing smooth muscle in the corpus cavernosum, leading to blood flow and an erection. If the action of nitric oxide is prolonged, it can result in a sustained erection, which can interfere with the normal progression of the sexual act. Question: A 39-year-old man presents with lower back pain. A history of present illness reveals that the pain started while he was playing golf, and he could not continue with the game. Upon waking up the next morning, he felt the pain radiating down his right leg. He has no past medical history and takes no medication. ###Options:
A.  Ankle jerk reflex
B.  knee jerk reflex
C.  Lumbar puncture
D.  Straight leg raise
E.  Head flexion in a sitting position

###Answer:
rationale:
A straight leg raise is performed and will reproduce the pain if a herniated disc is compressing the nerve root. This can be done seated or supine. Patients with tight hamstrings may have a false positive when tested in the supine position.

Deep tendon reflexes can be normal, decreased, or absent with nerve root compression. Many pathologies can affect them.

The crossed straight leg raise is less sensitive but more specific. It is more specific for disc herniation. This maneuver reproduces the pain in the leg when you raise the contralateral leg.

Head flexion used for Lhermitte's sign causes a sudden sensation resembling an electric shock that passes down the back of the neck and into the spine and may then radiate out into the arms and legs. This is usually caused by cervical cord compression.
E: Head flexion in a sitting position
model rationale: The most appropriate physical examination maneuver in this case is D. Straight leg raise. The patients symptoms are consistent with a possible herniated disc in the lumbar spine, which can cause sciatica. The straight leg raise test is a simple and effective way to assess for nerve root irritation in the lumbar spine. It involves passively flexing the patients knee while keeping the hip straight, which can elicit pain or a positive sign if the nerve root is irritated. Ankle jerk reflex A is more indicative of pathology in the distal lower extremity, knee jerk reflex B assesses the patellar tendon reflex, which is less useful in this case, lumbar puncture C is not typically performed as an initial examination maneuver, and head flexion in a sitting position E does not specifically assess for lumbar spine pathology. ###Answer:
rationale: rheumatic heart disease can lead to damage and scarring of the heart valves, particularly the mitral valve. model rationale: The correct answer is D. Stroke. In children, the most common presentation of rheumatic heart disease is mitral stenosis, and the most common complication of mitral stenosis is stroke. Other complications such as pericarditis, heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and myocardial infarction are less common in children with untreated rheumatic heart disease. Reference Ghai Essential of Pediatrics, Eighth Edition, page 406.

Question: A 65-year-old woman presents to a clinic for a preoperative visit before total hip arthroplasty. The clinician discusses medications to prevent deep vein thrombosis postoperatively and potential reversal agents in the setting of bleeding. The medication the clinician plans to use may be reversed by protamin sulfate. What is the mechanism of action of this medication?
###Options:
A.  Enhances the action of antithrombin III
B.  Direct inhibition of thrombin (factor II)
C.  Competitive inhibition of plasminogen
D.  Inhibition of vitamin K 2,3-epoxide reductase
E.  indirect inhibition of thrombin (factor II)

###Answer:
rationale:
Unfractionated heparin is indicated for both the prevention and treatment of thrombotic events such as deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and atrial fibrillation.

Heparin can also prevent excessive coagulation during cardiac surgery, extracorporeal circulation, or dialysis, including continuous renal replacement therapy.

Unfractionated heparin activates antithrombin III to inhibit Xa indirectly. Enoxaparin inhibits Xa. Both of these medications may be reversed with protamine sulfate.

Various medications are available for prophylaxis for deep venous thrombosis (DVT) after joint replacement surgery. They have various modes of action, metabolism, side effects, and level of lab monitoring. Warfarin inhibits vitamin K 2,3-epoxide reductase and may be reversed using fresh frozen plasma and vitamin K. Direct Xa inhibitor drugs include rivaroxaban, apixaban, and edoxaban. They all include xa-ban in their names for easy recognition and do not require laboratory monitoring. Their half-life ranges from 8 to 12 hours. Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor. Fondaparinux is an indirect Xa inhibitor that acts through antithrombin III.
A: Enhances the action of antithrombin III
model rationale: The correct answer is E. indirect inhibition of thrombin factor II. The medication the clinician plans to use is an indirect inhibitor of thrombin factor II. Protamin sulfate can be used to reverse the effects of this medication if bleeding occurs. This medication works by binding to antithrombin III, which then binds to thrombin factor II and its cofactor thrombomodulin on endothelial cells. This complex formation inactivates thrombin and other coagulation factors, thereby preventing the formation of blood clots. Reference Harrisons Principles of Internal Medicine, 18th edition, chapter 244. Please let me know if you would like me to explain anything else.

Infection with schistosoma parasites can cause inflammation and damage to the liver and spleen, leading to their enlargement.

Additionally, the fact that he lives in an area where schistosomiasis is endemic further supports this diagnosis. Schistosomiasis is caused by parasitic worms that infect the blood vessels and can lead to various symptoms, including gastrointestinal bleeding and hepatosplenomegaly. Amoebiasis typically presents with dysentery and liver abscesses, but not hepatosplenomegaly. Giardiasis causes malabsorption and steatorrhea, but not bloody diarrhea. Typhoid fever presents with fever, abdominal pain, and constipation, but not bloody diarrhea or hepatosplenomegaly. Hookworm infection causes iron deficiency anemia and protein malnutrition, but not hepatosplenomegaly.

However, the presence of two separate placental masses is highly suggestive of dichorionic twins, as monochorionic twins typically share a single placenta. A bicornuate uterus would be a uterine anomaly and is not directly related to the chorionicity of twins.

Question: The following physiological measurements are increased in normal
healthy pregnancy EXCEPT:
###Options:
A.  Pulse rate.
B.  Cardiac output.
C.  Glomerular filtration rate.
D.  Serum colloid osmotic pressure.
E.  Red cell mass.

###Answer:
rationale: All the factors mentioned in the choices above increase in pregnancy except the colloid osmotic pressure
model rationale: The answer is D. Serum colloid osmotic pressure. The rationale for this answer is that during normal pregnancy, there is a decrease in serum colloid osmotic pressure due to a dilutional effect from increased plasma volume. This decrease is necessary to accommodate the increased blood volume required to support the growing fetus. In contrast, pulse rate, cardiac output, glomerular filtration rate, and red cell mass all increase during pregnancy to meet the metabolic demands of the mother and the fetus.

Multiple sclerosis is a neurological condition that typically affects the central nervous system, but it does not usually present with the acute onset of hypopituitarism. E. Pituitary adenoma is a slowgrowing tumor that would not typically cause acute onset of symptoms. Therefore, the most likely cause of the patients symptoms is pituitary necrosis secondary to her postpartum

Question: A 60-year-old white woman with non ischemiccardiomyopathy returns to clinic for follow-up. Her EF is30% and she has NYHA class III symptoms despitetherapy with an ACE inhibitor, beta-blocker, andfurosemide.Which of the following agents if added to her regimencould lower mortality?
###Options:
A.  Amlodipine
B.  Spironolactone
C.  Digoxin
D.  Amiodarone

###Answer:
rationale: In the Randomised Aldactone Evaluation Study (RALES)(N Engl J Med. 1999;341 :709-717), Pitt and colleaguesshowed that after 2 years of follow-up, spironolactonecompared to placebo had a 30% reduction in mortality(from both progressive CHF and sudden death) andimprovement in symptoms. Patients in the study weresimilar to this patient in that they had NYHA functionalclass III or IV and low left ventricular EF, with mean EF of25%.
model rationale: The correct answer is B. Spironolactone. The rationale is that in patients with heart failure and reduced ejection fraction EF, adding an ACE inhibitor, betablocker, and diuretic is standard therapy. Spironolactone is a potassiumsparing diuretic that has been shown to reduce mortality in patients with heart failure and reduced EF, particularly when there is evidence of fluid overload. Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker that does not have the same mortality benefits in heart failure. Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside that is sometimes used to improve symptoms in patients with heart failure with reduced EF, but it has not been shown to reduce mortality. Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic agent that is not typically used in patients with heart failure with reduced EF unless there is a specific indication for its use. Therefore, the addition of spironolactone to this patients regimen could potentially lower her mortality. Please let me know if you would like more information or if you have any other questions.

Question: Question: Which hormone is responsible for regulating blood sugar levels in the body?
###Options:
A.  Insulin
B.  Thyroxine
C.  Adrenaline
D.  Growth hormone
E.  Epinephrine

###Answer:
rationale: Insulin is the hormone responsible for regulating blood sugar levels in the body. It is produced by the pancreas and helps cells absorb glucose from the bloodstream to use it for energy or storage. In conditions like diabetes mellitus, either the body doesn't produce enough insulin or the cells do not respond properly to insulin, leading to high blood sugar levels
model rationale: The answer is A Insulin. Insulin is a hormone produced by the pancreas that plays a crucial role in regulating blood sugar levels. It helps to lower blood glucose levels by facilitating the uptake of glucose into cells, particularly in the liver, muscles, and adipose tissue. Insulin also promotes the storage of glucose as glycogen and inhibits the breakdown of glycogen to glucose. Thyroxine, adrenaline, growth hormone, and epinephrine are not directly involved in the regulation of blood sugar levels. Thyroxine is a thyroid hormone that regulates metabolism, adrenaline and epinephrine are both catecholamines that stimulate the bodys fightorflight response, and growth hormone is involved in growth, cell reproduction, and metabolism. None of these hormones have the same primary role as insulin in regulating blood sugar levels.

Question: You have been monitoring a 29-year-old woman in your clinic who has a history ofmechanical mitral valve replacement. She has been taking warfarin foranticoagulation since her valve was replaced 18 months ago. She now tells you thatshe is contemplating pregnancy.What is the most reasonable option for anticoagulation in this patient?
###Options:
A.  Discontinue warfarin and initiate subcutaneous heparin twice daily to goal activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) of at least twice the upper limit of the control, restart warfarin at the beginning of the second trimester, then switch back to subcutaneous heparin at around 36 weeks and continue this until delivery
B.  Continue warfarin until week 36, keeping her INR between 2.5 and 3.5, then discontinue all anticoagulation and coordinate with her obstetrician to schedule an elective Caesarian section 5 days after the last dose of warfarin
C.  Discontinue warfarin and initiate weight-based dose-adjusted low molecular weight I heparin until delivery so that there will not be a need to acquire blood work to monitor her anticoagulation
D.  None of the above. Pregnancy is contraindicated

###Answer:
rationale: Warfarin is associated with the lowest rate of valve thrombosis in pregnant women.However, because it crosses the placenta, it can cause birth defects and evenspontaneous abortion. The risk is almost exclusively when the fetus is exposedduring the first 12 weeks of gestation. After 12 weeks, warfarin is considered safe,but should be discontinued approximately 2-3 weeks before delivery to avoid havingthe patient fully anticoagulated at the time of delivery. Both unfractionated and lowmolecular-weight heparin (LMWH) require close monitoring to ensure adequateanticoagulation. If unfractionated heparin is used, the goal aPTT should be at leasttwice control. With LMWH, the anti-Xa level should be between 0.7 and 1.2 U/mL 4hours after administration.
A: Discontinue warfarin and initiate subcutaneous heparin twice daily to goal activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) of at least twice the upper limit of the control, restart warfarin at the beginning of the second trimester, then switch back to subcutaneous heparin at around 36 weeks and continue this until delivery
B: Continue warfarin until week 36, keeping her INR between 2.5 and 3.5, then discontinue all anticoagulation and coordinate with her obstetrician to schedule an elective Caesarian section 5 days after the last dose of warfarin
C: Discontinue warfarin and initiate weight-based dose-adjusted low molecular weight I heparin until delivery so that there will not be a need to acquire blood work to monitor her anticoagulation
D: None of the above. Pregnancy is contraindicated
model rationale: The correct answer is A. Discontinue warfarin and initiate subcutaneous heparin twice daily to goal activated partial thromboplastin time aPTT of at least twice the upper limit of the control, restart warfarin at the beginning of the second trimester, then switch back to subcutaneous heparin at around 36 weeks and continue this until delivery. This is the most reasonable option because it balances the need for anticoagulation during pregnancy with the potential risks of warfarin exposure to the fetus. The American Heart Association recommends this approach for patients with prosthetic heart valves who require anticoagulation during pregnancy. Warfarin is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects, so alternative anticoagulants like subcutaneous heparin are used. Heparin does not cross the placenta, making it safer for the fetus. However, heparin requires monitoring of aPTT levels, which necessitates frequent blood draws. The other options are not recommended because they either expose the fetus to warfarin or do not provide adequate anticoagulation during pregnancy. Discontinuing all anticoagulation and scheduling an elective Caesarian section would not provide adequate protection

Question: Tropical chronic pancreatitis affectsthe younger age group from poorsocioeconomic strata in developingcountries. Which of the followingstatements about the conditionare false?
###Options:
A.  A It is caused by ingestion of cassava (tapioca), a root vegetable, which contains derivatives of cyanide. The concurrent absence ofsulphur-containing amino acid in the diet prevents the cyanide from being detoxified in the liver, leading to cyanogen toxicity and the disease.
B.  B It is caused by alcoholism.
C.  C Patients present with extensive pancreatic periductal fibrosis, intraductal calcium carbonate stones and type I diabetes mellitus.
D.  D Patients show pancreatic calcification in the form of discrete stones on straight abdominal X-ray. Ultrasound and CT scans of the pancreas confirm the disease.
E.  E Patients need medical support for exocrine and endocrine pancreatic insufficiency and treatment for pain. Some require surgery.

###Answer:
rationale: A, C, D, EThe disease is not caused by alcohol ingestion but by derivatives of cyanide in cassava(tapioca), which is eaten as a staple diet; hence, it is a disease present in families. Patientspresent with abdominal pain, thirst, polyuria, weight loss due to malnutrition and featuresof gross pancreatic insufficiency. ERCP is used as a therapeutic procedure. Surgery isnecessary for intractable pain, particularly for stones in a dilated pancreatic duct. The choiceof procedure is usually a lateral pancreaticojejunostomy. Resectional surgery is used as a lastresort for intractable pain.
A: A It is caused by ingestion of cassava (tapioca), a root vegetable, which contains derivatives of cyanide. The concurrent absence ofsulphur-containing amino acid in the diet prevents the cyanide from being detoxified in the liver, leading to cyanogen toxicity and the disease.
B: B It is caused by alcoholism.
C: C Patients present with extensive pancreatic periductal fibrosis, intraductal calcium carbonate stones and type I diabetes mellitus.
D: D Patients show pancreatic calcification in the form of discrete stones on straight abdominal X-ray. Ultrasound and CT scans of the pancreas confirm the disease.
E: E Patients need medical support for exocrine and endocrine pancreatic insufficiency and treatment for pain. Some require surgery.
model rationale: The correct answer is B. It is caused by alcoholism. Rationale Tropical chronic pancreatitis is not caused by alcoholism. It is typically associated with malnutrition, especially the consumption of cassava, and has a strong genetic predisposition. Patients present with chronic abdominal pain, diabetes, and pancreatic calcifications. The condition is more prevalent in younger individuals from lower socioeconomic backgrounds in developing countries. The other options are true statements about tropical chronic pancreatitis. The disease is indeed associated with the consumption of cassava and malnutrition A, it can lead to pancreatic periductal fibrosis, intraductal calcium carbonate stones, and type I diabetes mellitus C, and imaging studies such as Xray, ultrasound, and CT scans can confirm the disease D. Patients with tropical chronic pancreatitis require medical support for exocrine and endocrine pancreatic insufficiency, as well as treatment for pain, and some may require surgery E. Therefore, option B is the only false statement about tropical chronic pancreatitis.

Question: Which of the following is a common complication of sickle cell disease in children living in malaria-endemic regions?
###Options:
A.  Priapism
B.  Aplastic crisis
C.  Stroke
D.  Leg ulcers
E.  Acute chest syndrome

###Answer:
rationale: The Acute chest syndrome is a common complication of sickle cell disease in children living in malaria-endemic regions is because malaria infection can trigger the sickling of red blood cells, leading to vaso-occlusion and inflammation in the lungs. This process contributes to the development of acute chest syndrome, which is characterized by chest pain, cough, fever, and difficulty breathing.
model rationale: The answer is C. Stroke. The rationale is that children with sickle cell disease in malariaendemic regions are at an increased risk of stroke due to the combination of hemolysis from sickle cell disease and infection with Plasmodium species, which can cause cerebral malaria and increased risk of stroke. Other complications such as priapism, aplastic crisis, leg ulcers, and acute chest syndrome are also associated with sickle cell disease but are not as directly linked to the interaction with malaria as stroke is.

Question:  22-year-old woman nursing her newborn develops a tender erythematous area around the nipple of her left breast. A  thick, yellow fl uid is observed to drain from an open fissure.  Examination of this breast fluid under the light microscope will most likely reveal an abundance of which of the following inflammatory cells?
###Options:

###Answer:
rationale: The answer is D: Neutrophils. The thick, yellow fluid draining  from the breast fissure in this patient represents a purulent exudate. Purulent exudates and effusions are associated with pathologic conditions such as pyogenic bacterial infections, in  which the predominant cell type is the segmented neutrophil (polymorphonuclear leukocyte). Mast cells (choice C) are granulated cells that contain receptors for IgE on their cell  surface. They are additional cellular sources of vasoactive  mediators, particularly in response to allergens. B lymphocytes  (choice A) and plasma cells (choice E) are mediators of  chronic inflammation and provide antigen-specific immunity  to infectious diseases. Diagnosis: Acute mastitis

The presence of a tender, erythematous area with a thick, yellow discharge indicates inflammation and pus formation. Neutrophils are the predominant inflammatory cells found in the pus of acute bacterial infections, such as acute mastitis. They are part of the bodys innate immune response and are responsible for phagocytosing and killing bacteria. Therefore, the examination of the breast fluid under the microscope is likely to reveal an abundance of neutrophils. The other options, including lymphocytes, eosinophils, mast cells, and plasma cells, are not typically the predominant cells seen in the pus of acute bacterial infections. Lymphocytes are more commonly associated with chronic infections or autoimmune diseases. Eosinophils are involved in parasitic infections and allergic reactions. Mast cells play a role in allergic reactions and anaphylaxis. Plasma cells are key players in antibody production and are typically seen in chronic inflammatory conditions. Therefore, the most likely finding on microscopic examination of the breast fluid in this patient is an abundance of neutrophils. The rationale for this answer is based on the clinical
